chapter_name: Economy of the United Arab Emirates
text:
The United Arab Emirates is a high-income developing market economy. The UAE's
economy is the 3rd largest in the Middle East (after Turkey and Saudi Arabia
), with a gross domestic product (GDP) of US$415 billion (AED 1.83 trillion)
in 2021-2023.

The UAE economy is heavily reliant on revenues from petroleum and natural gas,
especially in Abu Dhabi. In 2009, more than 85% of the UAE's economy was based
on the oil exports. In 2011, oil exports accounted for 77% of the UAE's state
budget. In recent years, there has been some economic diversification,
particularly in Dubai. Abu Dhabi and other UAE emirates have remained
relatively conservative in their approach to diversification. Dubai has far
smaller oil reserves than its counterparts.

Tourism is one of the biggest non-oil sources of revenue in the UAE. A massive
construction boom, an expanding manufacturing base, and a thriving services
sector are helping the country to diversify its economy. In 2007, there was US
$350 billion worth of active construction projects.

The UAE is a member of the World Trade Organization and OPEC.

• The UAE's economy ranks as the 3rd largest in the Middle East, following Turkey and Saudi Arabia.
• The gross domestic product (GDP) of the UAE was US$415 billion (AED 1.83 trillion) during the period 2021-2023.
• The UAE economy is heavily dependent on revenues from petroleum and natural gas, with Abu Dhabi being the primary center for these resources.
• In 2009, over 85% of the UAE's economy was based on oil exports, indicating a strong reliance on the petroleum sector.
• By 2011, oil exports accounted for 77% of the UAE’s state budget, underscoring the fiscal importance of hydrocarbons.
• Economic diversification efforts have increased in recent years, particularly in Dubai, which has smaller oil reserves compared to other emirates.
• Abu Dhabi and other emirates have maintained a relatively conservative approach to economic diversification compared to Dubai.
• Tourism is one of the largest non-oil revenue sources in the UAE, contributing significantly to economic diversification.
• The UAE has experienced a massive construction boom, supported by an expanding manufacturing base and a thriving services sector, aiding economic diversification.
• In 2007, the UAE had US$350 billion worth of active construction projects, reflecting rapid infrastructure and development growth.
• The UAE is a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), facilitating its integration into the global trading system.
• The UAE is also a member of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), aligning it with other major oil-producing nations.
generated_detailed_content: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is classified as a high-income developing market economy, reflecting its substantial wealth combined with ongoing efforts to modernize and diversify its economic base. This classification denotes a nation that, while possessing significant financial resources and infrastructure, continues to develop its institutional frameworks and market mechanisms to achieve sustained economic growth. The UAE’s economic status is bolstered by its strategic geographic location, abundant natural resources, and a government committed to fostering a business-friendly environment. These factors collectively contribute to its recognition as a dynamic and rapidly evolving economy within the global context. In terms of regional economic rankings, the UAE holds the position of the third-largest economy in the Middle East, trailing only Turkey and Saudi Arabia. This ranking underscores the country’s significant role in the economic landscape of the region, where it competes with larger and more populous nations. The UAE’s economic prominence is not solely a function of its natural resource wealth but also its diversified sectors, including finance, trade, tourism, and real estate. Its strategic initiatives to attract foreign investment and develop infrastructure have further cemented its status as a leading economic hub in the Middle East. Between 2021 and 2023, the gross domestic product (GDP) of the UAE was estimated at approximately US$415 billion, equivalent to AED 1.83 trillion. This substantial GDP figure reflects the cumulative output of the country's various economic sectors, including hydrocarbons, manufacturing, services, and tourism. The UAE’s GDP growth during this period was influenced by global economic conditions, oil price fluctuations, and the success of diversification policies. The government’s focus on sustainable development and innovation has also played a critical role in maintaining steady economic expansion despite external challenges. The UAE’s economy has historically been heavily dependent on revenues generated from petroleum and natural gas, with the emirate of Abu Dhabi serving as the primary center for these vital resources. Abu Dhabi possesses the largest share of the country’s oil reserves and natural gas fields, making it the dominant contributor to the UAE’s hydrocarbon sector. This dependence on fossil fuels has shaped the country’s fiscal policies, infrastructure development, and international trade relationships. The wealth generated from oil and gas exports has enabled the UAE to invest in large-scale infrastructure projects and social programs, laying the foundation for its modern economy. In 2009, the UAE’s reliance on oil exports was particularly pronounced, with over 85% of the economy directly based on these revenues. This figure illustrates the extent to which the country’s economic health was tied to the global oil market and the production capacity of its hydrocarbon sector. The dominance of oil exports at this time underscored the vulnerability of the UAE’s economy to fluctuations in oil prices and international demand. It also highlighted the imperative for the government to pursue economic diversification strategies to reduce dependence on a single commodity. By 2011, oil exports accounted for approximately 77% of the UAE’s state budget, further emphasizing the fiscal importance of hydrocarbons to the country’s public finances. This reliance meant that government revenues, which fund public services, infrastructure, and social welfare programs, were closely linked to the performance of the oil sector. The significant contribution of oil exports to the state budget underscored the challenges faced by policymakers in managing economic volatility and underscored the urgency of developing alternative revenue streams to ensure fiscal sustainability. In response to the risks associated with heavy dependence on oil, economic diversification efforts have increased markedly in recent years, particularly in the emirate of Dubai. Unlike Abu Dhabi, Dubai possesses relatively smaller oil reserves, which has historically necessitated a broader economic base. Dubai’s diversification strategy has focused on sectors such as finance, real estate, tourism, aviation, and trade, transforming it into a global business and tourism hub. These efforts have been supported by government policies aimed at attracting foreign investment, developing free zones, and enhancing infrastructure, which collectively have reduced the emirate’s vulnerability to oil market fluctuations. While Dubai has aggressively pursued diversification, Abu Dhabi and other emirates have maintained a comparatively conservative approach to economic diversification. Abu Dhabi, endowed with the largest hydrocarbon reserves, has continued to rely significantly on oil revenues but has also initiated gradual diversification programs targeting sectors like renewable energy, aerospace, and finance. Other emirates, with smaller economies and resource bases, have focused on niche sectors and regional economic integration. This variance in diversification strategies reflects differing resource endowments, economic priorities, and development trajectories within the federation. Tourism has emerged as one of the largest non-oil revenue sources in the UAE, playing a pivotal role in the country’s economic diversification. The UAE has invested heavily in developing world-class tourist destinations, luxury hotels, cultural attractions, and entertainment venues, attracting millions of visitors annually. Iconic projects such as the Burj Khalifa, Palm Jumeirah, and various theme parks have positioned the UAE as a premier global tourist destination. The tourism sector not only generates direct revenue but also stimulates growth in related industries, including retail, hospitality, transportation, and real estate, thereby broadening the economic base beyond hydrocarbons. The UAE has also experienced a massive construction boom, which has been a key driver of economic diversification. This boom has been supported by an expanding manufacturing base and a thriving services sector, both of which have contributed to the development of a more balanced and resilient economy. The construction industry has been instrumental in building the country’s infrastructure, including residential, commercial, and industrial projects, as well as transportation networks. The growth of manufacturing, particularly in sectors such as aluminum production, petrochemicals, and building materials, has complemented construction activities and provided employment opportunities. Meanwhile, the services sector, encompassing finance, education, healthcare, and information technology, has expanded rapidly, reflecting the UAE’s transition toward a knowledge-based economy. In 2007, the scale of the UAE’s construction activities was exemplified by the presence of approximately US$350 billion worth of active construction projects. This staggering figure highlighted the country’s rapid infrastructure and development growth during that period, driven by both public and private sector investments. The construction projects ranged from iconic skyscrapers and luxury residential complexes to transportation infrastructure such as airports, ports, and metro systems. This period of intense development not only transformed the physical landscape of the UAE but also contributed significantly to GDP growth and employment generation, reinforcing the country’s economic diversification objectives. The UAE’s integration into the global economy has been facilitated by its membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO). As a WTO member, the UAE has committed to adhering to international trade rules and regulations, promoting free trade, and reducing trade barriers. This membership has enhanced the country’s ability to attract foreign investment, expand its export markets, and participate in global value chains. The UAE’s strategic location as a gateway between East and West, combined with its open trade policies, has enabled it to become a major re-export hub and a critical node in international trade networks. Additionally, the UAE is a member of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), aligning it with other major oil-producing nations. This membership allows the UAE to coordinate oil production policies, influence global oil prices, and collaborate on matters related to the petroleum industry. Participation in OPEC has provided the UAE with a platform to engage with key oil producers and to contribute to the stability of the global oil market. It also underscores the continued importance of hydrocarbons to the country’s economy, even as diversification efforts progress. Through its OPEC membership, the UAE balances its role as a significant oil exporter with its ambitions for broader economic development.

2018. A third of the GDP is from oil revenues. The economy was expected to
grow 4–4.5% in 2013, compared to 2.3–3.5% over the previous five years. Since
independence in 1971, UAE's economy has grown by nearly 231 times to AED1.45
trillion in 2013. The non-oil trade has grown to AED1.2 trillion, a growth of
around 28 times from 1981 to 2012.

The UAE's economy is one of the most open worldwide, and its economic history
goes back to the times when ships sailed to India, along the Swahili coast, as
far south as Mozambique.

The UAE economy has been ‘inspected’ by international economic institutions on
a regular basis, generally receiving good reports on economic developments.
International Monetary Fund (IMF) expected UAE's economic growth to increase
to 4.5% in 2015, compared to 4.3% in 2014. The IMF ascribed UAE's potentially
strong economic growth in World Economic Outlook Report to the increased
contribution of non-petroleum sectors, which registered a growth average of
more than 6% in 2014 and 2015. Such contribution includes banking, tourism,
commerce and real estate. Increase of Emirati purchasing power and
governmental expenditures in infrastructure projects have considerably
increased.[_citation needed_]

Internationally, UAE is ranked among the top 20 for global service business,
according to AT Kearney, the top 30 on the WEF "most-networked countries" and
in the top quarter as a least corrupt country per the TI's corruption index.

The government of the United Arab Emirates announced a broad restructuring and
merger of more than 50% of its federal agencies, including ministries and
departments, in an attempt to deal with and recover from the economic shocks
following months-long coronavirus lockdown.

The absence of a centralized economic framework meant that economic policies and development initiatives were largely confined within the borders of individual emirates, which maintained their own traditional industries and modes of commerce. This fragmented economic landscape was characterized by subsistence activities and limited integration among the emirates, reflecting the socio-political realities of the time. The primary economic activities sustaining the populations of the emirates prior to unification were pearl diving, seafaring, and fishing, which collectively formed the backbone of the regional economy. Pearl diving was particularly significant, with coastal communities relying heavily on the collection and trade of natural pearls, which were highly valued in international markets. Seafaring facilitated trade and communication with neighboring regions, while fishing provided a vital source of food and income for coastal inhabitants. These traditional livelihoods shaped the social and economic fabric of the emirates, fostering a maritime culture deeply connected to the Arabian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. However, the traditional pearl diving industry experienced a sharp decline in the early 20th century, primarily due to the introduction and widespread adoption of Japanese cultured pearls, which flooded the global market and drastically reduced the demand for natural pearls. This economic disruption coincided with the discovery of commercially viable oil reserves in the region, which began to transform the economic prospects of the emirates. The newfound oil wealth offered an alternative source of income that gradually supplanted the pearl industry, providing the financial means for modernization and infrastructural development. His vision emphasized the equitable distribution of oil wealth to foster economic growth and enhance the quality of life for all citizens. Under his leadership, the UAE transitioned from a collection of small, economically isolated communities into a unified, rapidly developing nation with a diversified economic base. His strategic foresight laid the groundwork for Dubai’s emergence as a regional and global commercial hub, attracting investment and fostering innovation. During the 1980s, Dubai’s economic diversification efforts gained significant momentum, focusing particularly on expanding trade and developing major shipping and logistics infrastructure. Additionally, the expansion of Dubai International Airport enhanced the emirate’s connectivity, positioning it as a critical node in global air transport networks. These infrastructural developments were instrumental in transforming Dubai’s economy from one reliant on oil revenues to a multifaceted commercial center. The strategic development of these transportation and logistics hubs catalyzed the rise of prominent global companies headquartered in Dubai, which played central roles in shipping, transportation, and logistics. Collectively, these enterprises exemplified Dubai’s successful economic diversification strategy and its integration into the global economy.

diversification, Dubai, which has far smaller oil reserves, was bolder in its
diversification policy. In 2011, oil exports accounted for 77% of the UAE's
state budget.

Dubai suffered from a significant economic crisis in 2007–2010 and was bailed

attributed to Abu Dhabi's petrodollars. In 2014, Dubai owed a total of $142
billion in debt. The UAE government has worked towards reducing the economy's
dependence on oil exports by 2030. Various projects are underway to help
achieve this, the most recent being the Khalifa Port, opened in the Emirate of
Abu Dhabi at the end of 2012. The UAE also won the right to host the World
Expo 2020, which is believed to have a positive effect on future growth,
although there are some skeptics which mention the opposite.

Over the decades, the Emirate of Dubai has started to look for additional
sources of revenue. High-class tourism and international finance continue to
be developed. In line with this initiative, the Dubai International Financial
Centre was announced, offering 55.5% foreign ownership, no withholding tax,
freehold land and office space and a tailor-made financial regulatory system
with laws taken from best practice in other leading financial centers, like
New York, London, Zürich and Singapore.[_citation needed_] A new stock market

also developed Internet and Media free zones, offering 100% foreign ownership,
no tax office space for the world's leading ICT and media companies, with the

leading companies have now set up branch offices, and even changed
headquarters to, there. Recent [when?] liberalization in the property market

construction and real estate sectors, with several signature developments,
such as the 2 Palm Islands, the World (archipelago), Dubai Marina, Jumeirah
Lake Towers, and a number of other developments, offering villas and high rise

operator of the Airbus A380 aircraft. As of 2001[update], budgeted government
revenues were about AED 29.7 billion, and expenditures were about AED 22.9
billion. In addition, to finding new ways of sustaining the national economy,
the UAE has also made progress in installing new, sustainable methods of
generating electricity. This is evidenced by various solar energy initiatives
at Masdar City and by other renewable energy developments in parts of the
country.

In addition, the UAE is starting to see the emergence of local manufacturing
as new source of economic development, examples of significant government-led
investments, such as Strata in the aerospace industry, under Mubadala, are
successful, while there are also small scale entrepreneurial ventures picking
up, such as Zarooq Motors in the automotive industry.

In August 2020, the Barakah nuclear power plant, the first nuclear power plant
in the Arab world, became operational.

In its hard push for economic diversification, the UAE had been increasing its
presence in Africa. One of the areas of interest had been clean energy, for

The city incorporates residential neighborhoods, business parks, and industrial zones, all integrated with advanced infrastructure and transportation networks. Dubai South’s development aligns with Dubai’s vision to become a global logistics and aviation center, facilitating economic diversification and sustainable growth. City Walk is an urban retail and residential complex that combines shopping, dining, and entertainment within an open-air environment. Located in the heart of Dubai, City Walk offers a pedestrian-friendly streetscape featuring international brands, gourmet restaurants, and cultural venues. The development integrates residential apartments and office spaces, creating a vibrant mixed-use district that appeals to residents, tourists, and business visitors alike. City Walk’s design emphasizes modern urban living with green spaces, public art installations, and community events, contributing to Dubai’s reputation as a city that blends innovation with lifestyle. Al Furjan is a residential community that offers villas and townhouses with a focus on family living and community amenities. Situated near Sheikh Zayed Road and the Expo 2020 site, Al Furjan was developed to provide affordable yet high-quality housing options for middle-income families. The community features landscaped parks, schools, retail centers, and mosques, fostering a neighborhood-oriented environment. Al Furjan’s design prioritizes pedestrian-friendly streets and communal spaces, reflecting the UAE’s emphasis on creating inclusive and sustainable residential areas. Dubai Sports City is a mixed-use development centered around sports facilities, residential units, and commercial spaces. The project includes stadiums, academies, and training centers dedicated to various sports such as cricket, football, and golf, positioning it as a hub for athletic excellence and sports tourism. Residential options within Dubai Sports City range from apartments to villas, catering to athletes, sports enthusiasts, and families. The integration of commercial outlets, hotels, and leisure amenities supports a vibrant community lifestyle, aligning with Dubai’s strategy to diversify its real estate offerings and promote healthy living. Dubai Motor City is a real-estate project focused on motorsports, incorporating racing tracks, residential areas, and commercial developments. Located near the Dubai Autodrome, the development includes a Formula 1-standard race circuit, karting tracks, and automotive-themed leisure facilities. Residential options within Dubai Motor City consist of apartments and villas designed to appeal to motorsport fans and professionals. The project aims to create a unique lifestyle destination that combines the thrill of motorsports with urban living, contributing to Dubai’s portfolio of specialized real estate developments. Saadiyat Island, located in Abu Dhabi, is a cultural and residential development that hosts a collection of world-class museums, luxury residences, and leisure facilities. The island is home to the Louvre Abu Dhabi, the upcoming Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, and the Zayed National Museum, establishing it as a major cultural hub in the UAE. Residential developments on Saadiyat Island offer premium villas and apartments set amidst landscaped parks and beachfront areas. The island’s master plan integrates cultural institutions with sustainable urban living, reflecting Abu Dhabi’s commitment to fostering arts, heritage, and high-quality residential environments. The World, the Palms, and the Palm represent a series of artificial island projects in Dubai, designed to expand waterfront real estate and tourism infrastructure. The Palm Jumeirah, completed in the early 2000s, is the most famous of these, shaped like a palm tree and hosting luxury hotels, villas, and apartments along its fronds and trunk. The Palm Jebel Ali and Palm Deira were planned as larger extensions but faced delays and modifications. The World Islands project consists of a collection of man-made islands arranged to resemble a map of the world, intended for private residences, resorts, and commercial developments. These projects showcase Dubai’s innovative approach to land reclamation and urban expansion, significantly increasing the city’s coastline and real estate offerings. Dubai Miracle Garden holds the distinction of being the world’s largest natural flower garden, featuring elaborate floral displays and landscaping that attract millions of visitors annually. Opened in 2013, the garden spans over 72,000 square meters and showcases more than 50 million flowers arranged in intricate patterns and themed installations. The garden operates seasonally, adapting its floral compositions to celebrate various events and holidays, making it a dynamic attraction within Dubai’s leisure and tourism sector. Dubai Miracle Garden exemplifies the city’s dedication to creating unique recreational spaces that combine natural beauty with artistic expression. Masdar City in Abu Dhabi represents an innovative urban development aiming to be a zero carbon, zero waste city focused on sustainability and clean technology. Launched in 2006 as a flagship project for renewable energy and sustainable urban planning, Masdar City incorporates solar power, energy-efficient buildings, and advanced waste management systems. The city is designed to minimize environmental impact while fostering innovation in clean technologies, serving as a hub for research institutions and green businesses. Although its development has evolved over time, Masdar City remains a pioneering model for sustainable urbanization in the Middle East and globally. Yas Island in Abu Dhabi is a major leisure and entertainment destination featuring a range of attractions that contribute to the emirate’s tourism and entertainment sectors. The island hosts Ferrari World, the world’s first Ferrari-branded theme park, which includes high-speed rides and automotive-themed experiences. Yas Marina Circuit, another key feature, is a premier motorsport venue that hosts the annual Formula 1 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, attracting international audiences and competitors. Beyond motorsports, Yas Island offers water parks, shopping malls, hotels, and golf courses, creating a comprehensive entertainment ecosystem that supports Abu Dhabi’s vision of becoming a global leisure destination.

Together, the DIFC and ADGM exemplify the UAE’s strategic vision to position itself as a leading financial hub in the Middle East and beyond.
